summary: A comprehensive breakdown of the Kenneth Goldsmith interview video, focusing on character involvement, scene composition, narrative progression, mood, thematic elements, and possible improvements.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a black screen that transitions to a title card reading "Centro de Cultura Digital MEMORIAL" in white text, accompanied by small colored squares. The scene then shifts to another title card stating "Entrevista a Kenneth Goldsmith" in blue text. Following this, a question in pink text appears on a black background, asking about Kenneth Goldsmith's class called "Uncreative Writing" and its design in response to technological and literary trends. The video then shows Kenneth Goldsmith seated in a room with abstract art on the walls, wearing a white suit and hat. He is barefoot and appears to be speaking, with subtitles in Spanish at the bottom of the screen. The subtitles translate to "It is a class in which students should not be creative or original, and if they are creative and original, I give them low grades." The video maintains a consistent setting and atmosphere, focusing on the interview with Kenneth Goldsmith.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a distinct, mechanical sound, resembling that of a race car engine. Subsequently, a male speaker begins to explain a class where students are expected to be both uncreative and unoriginal. He further elaborates that if students exhibit creativity or originality, they are marked down, and as a result, they learn to be uncreative.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with a beard and wearing a hat, white suit, and white pants is seated on a black chair in an art gallery. He is surrounded by three large framed artworks on the wall behind him, each featuring abstract designs in black, blue, and red. The man appears to be engaged in a conversation, as indicated by the Spanish subtitles at the bottom of the screen. The subtitles read: "Así que deben apropiarse y no escribir nada original, no deben pretender que cualquier cosa que escriben es original, deben fingir que textos que no son suyos lo son, y mis estudiantes ya son buenos escritores." This translates to "So they should appropriate and not write anything original, they should not pretend that anything they write is original, they should pretend that texts that are not theirs are theirs, and my students are already good writers." The man's relaxed posture and the calm atmosphere of the gallery suggest a reflective and educational setting. The video maintains a consistent focus on the man and the artworks, with no significant changes in the environment or the man's position throughout the sequence.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker, discussing the act of appropriating and plagiarizing, emphasizing that they should not write anything original. The speaker mentions claiming texts as their own and then comments on how his students are already good writers, so he doesn't need to make them better.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with a beard and wearing a hat, white jacket, and white pants is seated on a black chair in an art gallery. He is surrounded by three large abstract paintings on the wall behind him, each featuring geometric designs in black, blue, and red. The man appears to be engaged in a conversation, as indicated by the Spanish subtitles that appear at the bottom of the screen. The subtitles read: "y son malos robando, porque llevan mucho tiempo robando y no se han preguntado qué se están robando y por qué se lo están robando. Entonces esto los obliga a teorizar su robo y los hace más inteligentes y mejores." (and they are bad thieves, because they have been stealing for a long time and have not asked themselves what they are stealing and why they are stealing it. So this forces them to theorize their theft and makes them smarter and better). The man's posture and facial expressions suggest he is discussing the concept of theft and its impact on the thieves' intelligence and behavior. The gallery setting, with its minimalist decor and focus on the artwork, creates an atmosphere of contemplation and intellectual discourse.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with one male speaker discussing "bad stealers," noting they have been stealing for a long time without thinking about what they steal or why. He says this forces them to "theorize their theft" and become "smarter and better." The clip ends abruptly without any background noise or music.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with a beard and wearing a hat, white jacket, and white pants is seated on a black chair in an art gallery. He is surrounded by three large abstract artworks on the wall behind him, featuring geometric patterns and lines in black, blue, and red. The man appears to be engaged in a conversation, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The text on the screen is in Spanish, with phrases such as "porque en este punto ya nadie" (because at this point no one), "es original," (is original), "ya nadie debe ser original," (no one should be original), "más bien se trata de la forma en que unen la información," (rather it is about the way they connect the information), and "es a lo que llegaremos en el futuro, no hay forma de revertir el reloj." (is what we will reach in the future, there is no way to reverse the clock). The man's expressions and gestures suggest he is discussing the nature of originality and creativity in art. The video transitions to a black screen with pink text that reads, "Tell us about your process for Un-creative writing," with a Spanish translation below it, "Platicanos sobre tu proceso para la Escritura no creativa." This text prompts viewers to reflect on their own creative processes, particularly in the context of writing. The video maintains a contemplative and introspective atmosphere throughout, focusing on the themes of creativity, originality, and the future of artistic expression.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker who suggests that nobody is original anymore, and should not be. He argues that progress comes from combining pre-existing information, implying that there is no going back. This is followed by the sound of a train, which dominates the audio suggesting movement and transportation.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man sitting in a chair in an art gallery, surrounded by three large abstract paintings on the wall behind him. He is dressed in a white suit and hat, with his legs crossed and hands resting on his lap. The man appears to be engaged in a conversation, as indicated by the subtitles in Spanish that appear at the bottom of the screen. The subtitles translate to phrases such as "I am interested in something and simply transcribe or copy it," "Well, the author is no longer...," "the genius is someone who can do something that no one else can do," and "and then, in fact, I think of this as the way people write now." The man's facial expressions and body language suggest he is deeply involved in the discussion, possibly reflecting on the nature of creativity and art. The gallery setting, with its minimalist decor and focus on the artwork, creates an atmosphere of contemplation and intellectual engagement.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a conversation. A male speaker admits to not writing anything original, stating "I don't write my own books." He then elaborates on his process of becoming interested in something and transcribing or copying it. The soundscape shifts to a faster-tempo, electronic, music, its mood driving and intense.  The male speaker returns, discussing authorship and the changing nature of genius. He compares the modern author to a hip-hop DJ, saying that the person has the best samples, and then is considered the best DJ. He states that writing paradigm is moving forward by the means of the hip hop DJ. The clip concludes with the continued electronic music.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man dressed in a white suit and hat is seated on a black chair in an art gallery, surrounded by three large abstract paintings on the wall behind him. The paintings feature intricate geometric designs in black, blue, and red. The man appears to be engaged in a conversation, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. Throughout the video, Spanish subtitles appear at the bottom of the screen, translating his words into English. The subtitles discuss the evolution of art and literature, mentioning that poetry was 50 years behind painting and that the art world has been open to new strategies that writing has not yet experimented with. The man continues to speak, and the subtitles change to discuss appropriation, describing it as something quite ancient. The setting remains consistent, with the man seated in the same position, and the background details, including the paintings and the gallery's white walls, remain unchanged. The atmosphere is calm and contemplative, focusing on the man's discussion about art and its historical context.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker, who begins by remarking, "In 1959 a poet named Brian Gysin," further elaborating on the fact that "poetry was 50 years behind painting." He speaks with a thoughtful and somewhat academic tone, emphasizing that "the art world has long been open to other strategies" and mentioning appropriation. The speaker contrasts this openness with the writing and music worlds, using the example of samples.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man dressed in a white suit and hat is seated on a black chair in an art gallery, surrounded by three large abstract paintings on the wall behind him. The paintings feature intricate designs with lines and shapes in black, blue, and red. The man appears to be engaged in a conversation, as indicated by the Spanish subtitles at the bottom of the screen, which translate to "And now, the world of literature is just arriving here, 100 years after Marcel Duchamp, the literature is finally taking a Duchampian strategy. I would say it is quite slow, quite behind, now." The scene transitions to a black screen with pink text asking, "Do you make a distinction between the practice of uncreative writing, reappropriation, recycling and plagiarism?" followed by the Spanish translation, "¿Haces alguna distinción entre la práctica de escritura no creativa, la reapropiación, el reciclaje y el plagio?" The video maintains a contemplative and intellectual atmosphere, focusing on the intersection of art, literature, and philosophical inquiry.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker commenting on how literature is "just getting to it" and implementing a "Duchampian strategy," suggesting it's slow and "pretty far behind right now." The audio then transitions abruptly to a louder ambience featuring the sounds of a moving vehicle or machinery, seemingly indicative of an outdoor or industrial setting.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man dressed in a white suit and hat is seated in a room adorned with abstract art pieces on the wall behind him. He appears to be engaged in a conversation, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The room has a modern and artistic atmosphere, with a light-colored floor and a white wall that serves as a backdrop for the vibrant artworks. The man's facial expression is focused and thoughtful, indicating that he is deeply involved in the discussion. On-screen text in Spanish appears, providing context to his dialogue. The text reads, "No todas son partes de la escritura no creativa, todas son diferentes estrategias adentro de la escritura no creativa," which translates to "Not all are parts of non-creative writing, they are all different strategies within non-creative writing." This suggests that the man is discussing various approaches to non-creative writing. The text continues with, "Lo que no es parte de la escritura no creativa sería el pastiche," meaning "What is not part of non-creative writing would be the pastiche," followed by, "o el tomar una línea de aquí o allá," which translates to "or taking a line from here or there." The man's gestures and the text indicate that he is explaining the concept of pastiche and its distinction from non-creative writing. The video maintains a consistent setting and atmosphere throughout, with the man's expressive gestures and the on-screen text providing a coherent narrative.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker explaining that certain elements are part of uncreative writing, different strategies within it. He then states what is not part of uncreative writing is pastiche or "taking a line from here or there", clarifying "that's not plagiarism".

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man dressed in a white suit and hat is seated in a room adorned with abstract art pieces on the wall behind him. He is engaged in a conversation, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The room has a modern and artistic atmosphere, with a light-colored floor and a white wall that serves as a backdrop for the artwork. The man appears to be discussing the concept of appropriation in art, referencing Marcel Duchamp and the idea of moving objects from one place to another to change their context. The text on the screen is in Spanish, with English translations provided in parentheses, posing questions about the implications of encouraging plagiarism and uncreative writing in an academic environment. The video transitions to a black screen with pink text asking, "Does encouraging plagiarism and uncreative writing put you in a difficult position in the academic environment where you work?" followed by the Spanish translation, "¿Crees que alentar el plagio y la escritura no creativa te ponen en una posición difícil en el ambiente académico en el que trabajas?" The video maintains a consistent focus on the man's discussion and the thought-provoking questions presented on the screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a single male speaker discussing plagiarism, distinguishing it from appropriation as taking something in its entirety and changing its context. His tone is explanatory and somewhat academic. The speech then fades out, transitioning into ambient sounds suggesting a train in motion, characterized by rhythmic, consistent sounds. This background noise is shortly accompanied by music, a somewhat dissonant and unsettling piece possibly in the experimental genre, which features industrial sounds alongside traditional musical elements.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man dressed in a white outfit and hat is seated on a black chair in a room adorned with three large abstract artworks on the wall behind him. The artworks feature intricate designs with lines and shapes in black, blue, and red. The man appears to be engaged in a conversation, as indicated by the Spanish subtitles that appear on the screen, discussing the nature of consent and the roles people play in certain activities. The subtitles translate to phrases like "No, es consensual," "Es como un club de sadomasoquismo," and "ningún animal fue lastimado en la formación de un escritor no creativo." The room has a minimalist aesthetic with a light-colored floor and a white wall, creating a calm and focused atmosphere. The video then transitions to a black screen with pink text asking, "How do you think the diversification of writing practices and media platforms has impacted the concept of audience?" followed by the Spanish translation, "¿Cómo crees que la diversificación de la práctica creativa y las plataformas digitales han impactado el concepto de audiencia?" This text prompts viewers to reflect on the changes in audience dynamics due to evolving writing practices and digital media platforms.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker describing a consensual activity, mentioning an "S&M club" and emphasizing that "nobody gets hurt." His tone is explanatory and slightly defensive. The speech is followed by a musical interlude, featuring a distorted electronic sound resembling a train whistle. This is layered over ambient background sounds that suggest an urban environment.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man dressed in a white suit and hat is seated on a black chair in an art gallery, surrounded by three large abstract paintings. The paintings feature intricate designs with lines and shapes in black, blue, and red. The man appears contemplative, with his hands clasped and legs crossed. Throughout the video, Spanish subtitles appear at the bottom of the screen, translating to English as follows: "I no longer believe we can understand the public," "I think there was a time," "when one could assume that there was an audience," "now the audience is so large and so blurry," "that we really have no idea who we are talking to," and "and I really don't think we are talking to anyone, I think no one is really paying attention." The gallery setting is minimalistic, with a light-colored floor and walls, and a small white object visible on the floor to the left of the man. The atmosphere is quiet and introspective, emphasizing the man's reflections on the nature of audience engagement in art.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with speech. A male speaker, with a somewhat somber tone, expresses his opinion that "we can't understand audience anymore." He continues, explaining how he feels there was a time when an audience could be assumed, but now the audience is "so big and so thin" that it's difficult to know who they're speaking to, and that he doesn't think anyone's paying attention. This is accompanied by a prominent vehicle sound, which suggests an outdoor setting.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man dressed in a white outfit and hat is seated on a chair in an art gallery, surrounded by three large abstract paintings on the wall behind him. The paintings feature intricate geometric designs in black, blue, and red. The man appears to be engaged in a conversation, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. Throughout the video, Spanish subtitles appear at the bottom of the screen, translating his words into English. The subtitles discuss the nature of modern communication and the way people interact with content online, suggesting that while we may be paying attention to headlines and tweets, we are not truly engaging with the content in the same way. The man emphasizes that this is a new situation and that there is no point in complaining about it, as things are simply the way they are. The setting is calm and focused, with the man's thoughtful expressions and gestures complementing the contemplative atmosphere of the gallery.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing people paying attention to "headlines and tweets" and things that "move very quickly" but not engaging with content as they once did. He states he doesn't think that's good or bad and that there's "no point complaining about it" since it's the way it is. Background noise, characterized by consistent and moderate volume, can be heard throughout the clip.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man dressed in a white suit and hat, seated in a room adorned with three large abstract artworks on the wall behind him. The artworks are characterized by geometric patterns and lines, with one being black and white, another blue and white, and the third red and white. The man appears to be engaged in a conversation, as indicated by the Spanish subtitles that translate to "then I prefer to deal with it," "adjust myself to it, and well," and "it's my problem, not a problem of culture." The scene transitions to a black screen with pink text asking, "If you were to write a text of your daily online routine, what would it read like?" followed by the Spanish translation, "Si tuvieras que escribir un texto sobre tu rutina en línea diaria, ¿qué escribirías?" The video then returns to the man, who continues speaking, with subtitles stating, "Ah, if I write a text about my daily online routine." The setting remains consistent throughout, with the man seated in front of the abstract artworks, creating a contemplative and artistic atmosphere.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with speech, a male voice explaining his preference to adjust to a situation, considering it "my problem, not the media" or "culture's problem". This is followed by the sound of a vehicle, likely an automobile, characterized by engine noise, which possibly indicates traffic. Then there's a shift back to speech, another male voice clarifying that he writes "the text of my daily online routine".

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with a beard and wearing a hat is seated in a room adorned with abstract art pieces on the wall behind him. He is dressed in a white outfit and is barefoot, sitting on a chair with his legs crossed. The man appears to be engaged in a conversation, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The room has a minimalist aesthetic, with a light-colored floor and a white wall, creating a calm and focused atmosphere. The abstract art pieces feature geometric patterns and lines, adding a modern and artistic touch to the setting. Throughout the video, Spanish subtitles appear at the bottom of the screen, providing translations of the man's dialogue. The subtitles discuss themes of memory, technology, and the future, with phrases like "Creo que la nueva memoria" (I believe the new memory) and "todo está archivado hoy en día" (everything is archived today). The man's expressions and gestures suggest he is deeply engaged in the topic, conveying a sense of contemplation and insight. The video maintains a consistent visual style, with the man remaining the central focus against the backdrop of the abstract art, emphasizing the connection between art, memory, and technology.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the nature of personal memoirs in relation to browser history. His tone is casual and conversational. He then notes that he is practically always online and feels "dead" when disconnected. After this, we hear the sound of tires rolling against pavement. Returning to the man, he discusses how memories are stored digitally on hard drives, the cloud, and social media. He seems unworried about remembering things, stating that "everything is archived now." He concludes that he can "google my memories" better than he can remember them himself, implying that he no longer needs to keep memories in his head.
